solution_line_template: For each type of shirt, he needed to buy, {total_employees} employees / {num_shirt_categories} = <<{total_employees}/{num_shirt_categories}={shirts_per_category}>>{shirts_per_category} shirts.

White women's T-shirts cost ${price_difference} less, or (${white_men_shirt_price}/shirt - ${price_difference}/shirt) * {shirts_per_category} shirts = ${white_men_shirt_price - price_difference}/shirt * {shirts_per_category} shirts = ${cost_white_women_shirts}.

Black women's T-shirts cost $ {price_difference} less, so (${black_men_shirt_price}/shirt - ${price_difference}/shirt) * {shirts_per_category} shirts = ${black_men_shirt_price - price_difference}/shirt * {shirts_per_category} shirts = $<<({black_men_shirt_price}-{price_difference})*{shirts_per_category}={cost_black_women_shirts}>>{cost_black_women_shirts}.

Now add up all these quantities to find the total: ${cost_white_men_shirts} + ${cost_white_women_shirts} + ${cost_black_men_shirts} + ${cost_black_women_shirts} = $<<{cost_white_men_shirts}+{cost_white_women_shirts}+{cost_black_men_shirts}+{cost_black_women_shirts}={total_cost}>>{total_cost}.
